factoid: The commander of the regiment turned to Prince Bagratión.
The commander of the regiment entreats Prince Bagratión to go back.
It was too dangerous for the commander of the regiment and his regiment to remain where they were.
The commander of the regiment repeatedly said, 'Please, your excellency, for God’s sake!'.
The commander of the regiment glanced for support at an officer of the suite.
The officer of the suite turned away from the commander of the regiment.
The commander of the regiment pointed out the bullets whistling, singing, and hissing around them.
The bullets whistling, singing, and hissing were continually around them.
The commander of the regiment spoke in a tone of entreaty and reproach.
The commander of the regiment said, 'We are used to it, but you, sir, will blister your hands.'.
The commander of the regiment spoke as if the bullets could not kill him.
The commander of the regiment's half-closed eyes added persuasiveness to his words.
The staff officer joined in the colonel’s appeals.
Prince Bagratión did not reply to the appeals.
Prince Bagratión gave an order to cease firing and re-form.
Prince Bagratión's order was to give room for the two approaching battalions.
While Prince Bagratión was speaking, the curtain of smoke that had concealed the hollow began to move from right to left.
The curtain of smoke was driven by a rising wind.
The hill opposite the hollow had the French moving about on it.
The hill opened out before them.
All eyes fastened involuntarily on the French column.
The French column advanced against them.
The French column wound down over the uneven ground.
One could see the soldiers’ shaggy caps.
One could distinguish the officers from the men.
One could see the standard flapping against its staff.
Someone in Prince Bagratión’s suite remarked, 'They march splendidly.'.
The head of the French column had already descended into the hollow.
The clash would take place on the side of the hollow where the head of the column had descended.
The remains of the regiment that had been in action rapidly formed up.
The remains of the regiment moved to the right.
Two battalions of the Sixth Chasseurs came from behind, dispersing the laggards, in fine order.
Before the battalions reached Prince Bagratión, the weighty tread of the mass of men marching in step could be heard.
On the left flank nearest to Prince Bagratión marched a company commander.
The company commander was a fine round-faced man.
The company commander had a stupid and happy expression.
The company commander had rushed out of the wattle shed.
The company commander thought only of how dashing he would appear as he passed the commander.
The company commander stepped lightly with his muscular legs as if sailing along.
The company commander stretched himself to his full height without the smallest effort.
The company commander's ease contrasted with the heavy tread of the soldiers keeping step with him.
The company commander carried close to his leg a narrow unsheathed sword.
The company commander looked at the superior officers and back at the men without losing step.
The company commander's body turned flexibly.
The company commander felt that all the powers of his soul were concentrated on passing the commander in the best possible manner.
The company commander felt happy because he believed he was doing it well.
The company commander repeated 'Left... left... left...' to himself at each alternate step.
The wall of soldiers burdened with knapsacks and muskets marched in step.
Each soldier in the wall repeated 'Left... left... left...' to himself at each alternate step.
A fat major skirted a bush, puffing and falling out of step.
A soldier who had fallen behind had his face showing alarm at his defection.
The soldier ran at a trot, panting to catch up with his company.
A cannon ball flew over the heads of Prince Bagratión and his suite.
The cannon ball fell into the column.
The cannon ball's fall was measured as 'Left... left!'.
The company commander shouted, 'Close up!' in jaunty tones.
The soldiers passed in a semicircle around the place where the cannon ball had fallen.
An old trooper on the flank, a noncommissioned officer, stopped beside the dead men.
The old trooper ran to catch up his line.
The old trooper fell into step with a hop.
The old trooper looked back angrily.
Through the ominous silence and the regular tramp of feet, one seemed to hear 'left... left... left.'.
Prince Bagratión said, 'Well done, lads!'.
A confused shout from the ranks said, 'Glad to do our best, your excellency!'.
A morose soldier marching on the left turned his eyes on Prince Bagratión as he shouted.
The morose soldier's expression seemed to say, 'We know that ourselves!'.
Another soldier shouted with his mouth wide open and passed on without looking round.
